  1. Read the Corruption Watch Report

    Featured in our Corruption Watch Report

    It's about communities collaborating around the fight against corruption. In this digital hub, people, groups of people, organisations etc, can start conversations that will contribute towards reducing the high levels of corruption in South Africa. Communities of people can collaborate in whatever area is of real importance to them. This may be schools, traffic authorities, etc. It's simple to sign up to the Connected hub, invite more people and start a conversation. Once people are sharing information here, they can also post photographs, video and more. READ OUR ANNUAL CORRUPTION REPORT AND JOIN THE COMMUNITY TODAY.

  2. Meet South Africa's corruption fighters

    Fighting corruption is up to every South African resident. We are the people on the ground and we can mobilise to decrease this scourge on our country. Start today by signing up to our community and become one of our corruption flighters.

    Easy steps to becoming a corruption fighter:

    1. Sign up on CorruptionWatch Connected.

    2. Invite friends and people who you know think the way you do about corruption.

    3. Start a project under CORRUPTION FIGHTERS where you can post documents, notes, images and video. You can also schedule an event.

    It's as simple as that to start fighting corruption.

    Report corruption

Why we're focused on building a community of activists and why you should join?

CorruptionWatch Connected is about mobilising a community of corruption fighters. Our experience over the short lifespan of our organisation, has shown us that many people living in South Africa are interested in being part of the fight. But we also understand that people want to report and combat corruption is many different ways. All those channels for reporting corruption are still there. This is a new one which allows us to engage with you and more importantly, you to engage with each other.

Our policy around using this great connected tool

* Be honest in your reporting

* Take care to use language that everyone will find respectful

* Continue to encourage your community to get involved on this connected platform, whether they're from your school, your municiple district, your organisation or your social circle

How to join

Simple click on Join the community and fill in some details. For those who feel they are able to do more from a position of remaining anonymous, please do so. But of course be anonymous for the right reason.

We look forward to welcoming you into this important community.

What can I do on this 'connect' site?

Welcome to Corruption Watch Connected. This is a platform for corruption fighters that are interested in collaborating with us at Corruption Watch and ALSO with each other. But how do you do this?

First step - register and set up your personal page. You're not obliged to upload an image but we'd love to know a bit about you. Tell us as much as you are comfortable to divulge.

Second step - take a look at the groups under the tab CORRUPTION FIGHTERS. We have started two groups for you to join and engage in. These are Election Watch a'nd Corruption in Schools.' But be assured that more groups are coming in the future. If these topics are of interest and you would like to join and contribute - simply join the group. Once in the group, you will see that you are able to load video, photos, comment on blogs, participate in discussions, and more. There are however other ways to collaborate.

Third step - collaborating with like-minded people. From your personal page, you are able to blog, add photos and videos and connect to other people. To become friends with individuals on the platform, simply go to PEOPLE, and click on Ask to be a Friend. This will send a message which the individual can accept.

We encourage you to engage and start collaborating. Tell your colleagues and friends and get them collaborating. This is the start of a community of activists and we welcome you.

For more information go to http://www.corruptionwatch.org.za/content/make-your-complaint

for more information go to http://www.corruptionwatch.org.za/content/sign-pledge

GROUPS YOU CAN JOIN TODAY

Corruption in Schools

A group committed to enaging around corruption related school issues, but a group where you are able to upload photos, videos, contribute to conversation and comment on blogs.

Election Watch

The upcoming April elections are already creating many conversations - the conversations we're interested in are those that involve corruption. Observe, report and engaging with us and with your fellow South Africans.

 

Corruption confirmed in 58% of reports received

HEROES AND ZEROS

Minister chooses a pricy drive

Our first zero for the year is North West premier Thandi Modise, whose purchase of a R1.3-million luxury car has outraged citizens.

In October 2013 finance minister Pravin Gordhan announced a range of measures aimed at curbing excessive public spending – the buying of cars was included in his anti-spending strategy.

Modise bought a swanky new BMW 750i, but officials in her office have defended the acquisition, saying that the car had been on order long before Gordhan’s austerity measures came into play. They have also said that the purchase complies with a rule in the ministerial handbook which states that the value of a car may not exceed 70% of the premier’s annual salary.

What is corruption?

Corruption is the abuse of public resources to enrich or give unfair advantage to individuals, their family or their friends. Corruption Watch is concerned with any such abuse of power or position by anyone at any level of government or in business.

Examples of public resources:

  • Money, goods, vehicles, buildings and any other resources that belong to the government
  • Pension funds and medical aid funds
  • Trade union money and resources
  • Lottery money
  • Donations to charities

Common forms of corruption:

  • A business or individual pays a bribe to a government official in order to be given a government contract or licence
  • The use of government-owned resources, such as motor vehicles, for private purposes
  • A government official takes advantage of his or her position to favour a family member or business associate for a job or tender contract. This is commonly called nepotism
  • A police officer solicits a bribe or a member of the public offers one in order to escape lawful punishment

Do you know how to report corruption to the public protector?

  • Help with a non-criminal case of corruption: the Public Protector

The Public Protector is an independent institution established under the Constitution (Section 182). It receives reports from any person who has a complaint of corruption that involves government departments, agencies or officials who violate their ethical codes or codes of conduct, as long as it is not a criminal case. (Criminal cases are received by the SAPS, see below.)

Reports can be made in person (the Public Protector has offices in every province) or through the website.

To report corrupt activity to the Public Protector, complete the online form or contact the Public Protector;

Tel: 0800 11 20 40 (toll free)

Email: registration2@pprotect.org

Fax: 012 362 3473
